timeline.bodyText: I would just say: get the Item where the bundle resides in. We should not support bundle shared between multiple items
timeline.author: abollini

timeline.bodyText: I would prefer to remove this test as this is an use case that we don't want to support
timeline.author: abollini

replies.bodyText:
I'm OK with this test, as it proves that we are only ever returning the FIRST bundle if somehow an Item did exist in multiple bundles.
That said, I think @abollini is correct that we need to add a special comment on this method.  I'd recommend we add JavaDocs or a comment above this test method to say:
This test proves that, if a bitstream is linked to multiple bundles, we only ever return the first bundle.  **NOTE: DSpace does NOT support or expect to have a bitstream linked to multiple bundles**.  But, because the database does allow for it, this test simply proves the REST API will respond without an error.
replies.author: tdonohue

timeline.bodyText: I would prefer to remove this test as this is an use case that we don't want to support
timeline.author: abollini

replies.bodyText:
Again, as before, I'm OK with this test, as it proves our REST API won't completely error out if somehow a site has a Bundle belonging to two Items.
That said, I agree with @abollini  that this isn't something we should actively support.  So, again, let's add some JavaDocs/comments to this test method to say something like:
This test proves that, if a bundle is linked to multiple items, we only ever return the first item. **NOTE: DSpace does NOT support or expect to have a bundle linked to multiple items**. But, because the database does allow for it, this test simply proves the REST API will respond without an error.
replies.author: tdonohue
